questions.text: A 50-year-old patient has a 2-year history of weight loss and diarrhoea. He also gives a history of episodes of flushing. VIP syndrome is considered by the admitting physician. Which one of the following is a feature of VIPoma syndrome?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • VIPomas [vasoactive intestinal peptide] originate in amine precursor uptake and decarboxylation (APUD) cells of the gastroenteropancreatic endocrine system and in adrenal or extra-adrenal neurogenic sites.
  • Features of VIP syndrome include watery diarrhoea (100%), hypochlorhydria (70% in adults), hyperglycemia (20-50% in adults), hypercalcemia (20-50% in adults), flushing (20% in adults) and hypokalemia due to diarrhoea.
  • Achlorhydria (lack of acidity from the stomach) is classically associated with VIPoma. It can be diagnosed by measuring acid output from nasogastric contents (NG tube).
  • Initial treatment is directed toward correcting volume and electrolyte abnormalities by using potassium chloride and sodium bicarbonate.
  • Octreotide controls diarrhoea in 80% of cases. Glucocorticoids reduce symptoms in 50% of patients with VIPoma.

questions.text: A 26-year-old woman with cystic fibrosis presents with abdominal pain. The abdominal pain is colicky and localised in the lower abdomen. On examination, she has pyrexia and tachycardia. Her abdomen was distended. There was guarding, and bowel sounds were present. Which of the following is likely to be the cause?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Meconium Ileus is the earliest clinical manifestation of cystic fibrosis (CF) and occurs in approximately 16% of patients with CF.
  • Contents of the intestinal lumen are often difficult to excrete, leading to meconium ileus (a presentation in 10-20% of newborns with CF) or distal intestinal obstructive syndrome in older individuals.
  • Signs of peritonitis include tenderness, abdominal wall oedema, distension, and clinical evidence of sepsis. A palpable mass may indicate pseudocyst formation.
  • Surgical exploration is indicated for patients with progressive distension, signs of peritonitis, or clinical deterioration.
  • Complicated Meconium Ileus requires resection more often than simple cases and always requires temporary stomas.

Explanation of incorrect options:

Renal calculi(Option A): Would cause flank pain, often colicky, without abdominal distension, guarding, or fever.

Ulcerative colitis(Option B): Presents with chronic bloody diarrhoea and urgency, but rarely causes colicky pain, distension, or acute obstruction in CF patients.

Irritable bowel syndrome(Option D): Causes intermittent crampy pain and altered bowel habits, without fever, guarding, distension, or tenderness.

questions.text:
A 43 year old woman presents with abdominal pain and watery diarrhea. She has joint pains and also has been investigated for infertility. She was given a proton pump inhibitor by her GP and this helped to relieve some of her symptoms.Investigations show:
Haemoglobin 13 g/dl
Calcium 11.5 mg/dl
Albumin 4.0 g/dl
Phosphate 2.4 mg/dl
CRP 10 mg/l
Endoscopy - multiple small duodenal ulcers
H. pylori test - negative
What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • MEN 1 would fit the clinical diagnosis. The abdominal symptoms are likely to be due to gastrinoma and hypercalcaemia due to a parathyroid adenoma.
  • Infertility could be explained by a prolactinoma.

Men 1:

MEN1 is an autosomal dominant syndrome caused by activating mutations in the MEN1 gene on chromosome 11, which encodes the tumour suppressor protein menin.

Hallmark Tumours associated with MEN 1:

  • Primary hyperparathyroidism
  • Pancreatic neuroendocrine tumours
  • Pituitary adenomas

Explanation of other options:

NSAID-induced ulceration(Option A) would cause features of peptic ulcer disease, like abdominal pain, nausea, vomiting, and melena and would not cause diarrhoea.

Small bowel Lymphoma(Option C) presents with a constellation of chronic diarrhoea, malabsorption, severe weight loss, clubbing and ankle oedema. Hypocalcaemia may occur.

Celiac disease(Option D) would cause features of malabsorption like steatorrhea, weight loss and features of vitamin deficiency like osteomalacia, hypocalcaemia.

questions.text: A 65-year-old woman has had a diagnosis of insulin-dependent diabetes mellitus (poorly controlled) for 25 years. She complains of repeated episodes of abdominal pain following meals. These episodes have become more frequent over the past 3 months. There is no abdominal tenderness on palpation. Which of the following is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Abdominal angina is postprandial pain that occurs in mesenteric vascular occlusive disease when blood flow to the colon is unable to meet visceral demands.
  • Atherosclerotic disease is the most common cause of abdominal angina. It frequently involves the ostia of the mesenteric vessels.
  • In most people, it is occlusion of the superior mesenteric artery that is responsible for the abdominal symptoms.
  • Diabetes, especially Type 2 diabetes, is associated with macrovascular disease.

Explanation of other options:

Cholecystitis(Option A): Characteristically causes RUQ pain, often aggravated by fatty meals, with tenderness and positive Murphy s sign and not postprandial diffuse pain without tenderness.

Hepatitis(Option B): May cause dull RUQ discomfort and elevated liver enzymes, but not colicky post-meal pain.

Chronic pancreatitis(Option D): Can cause epigastric pain that may radiate to the back and may worsen with meals, but it usually presents with malabsorption and tenderness-not specifically postprandial crampy pain in diabetic atherosclerosis.

questions.text: A 66-year-old man is investigated for lower back pain. He also complains of weight loss and fevers. On reviewing his history, he has been told before that he has ankylosing spondylitis. On admission, his blood tests show a urea of 66 mg/dl and a creatinine of 3.50 mg/dl. An ultrasound of the kidneys shows hydronephrosis bilaterally. CT scan shows fibrotic para-aortic masses. Which of the following is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • The symptoms of fever, weight loss and lower back pain are classical for retroperitoneal fibrosis.
  • RPF is characterised by fibrous tissue encircling the abdominal aorta and ureters, leading to obstructive uropathy, notably bilateral hydronephrosis and renal failure.
  • Patients typically present in their 40s-60s with constitutional symptoms: weight loss, fever, malaise, and dull back or abdominal pain.
  • CT imaging commonly shows a soft-tissue mass surrounding the aorta and encasing the ureters, consistent with the CT findings described.
  • There is a documented association between ankylosing spondylitis (AS) and secondary RPF, likely related to immune-mediated inflammation or aortitis in AS driving fibrotic reactions.
  • There is an association with inflammatory conditions such as SLE, rheumatoid arthritis, ankylosing spondylitis, Hashimoto's thyroiditis and glomerulonephritis.

Explanation of other options:

Carcinoid syndrome(Option A): May cause fibrosis (carcinoid heart disease or mesenteric fibrosis) and flushing/diarrhoea, but this scenario lacks typical carcinoid features and hepatic/mesenteric NET masses-not para-aortic mass compressing ureters.

Amyloidosis(Option C): Can involve kidneys, cause chronic renal failure or hepatosplenomegaly, but is not associated with retroperitoneal fibrotic masses or ureter obstruction on imaging. Macroglossia, Raccoon eyes, and anaemia are features of amyloidosis.

Metastatic bladder cancer(Option D): Would more likely show bladder involvement or lymphadenopathy rather than a confluent para-aortic fibrotic mass encasing vasculature and ureters.

Key takeaways:

Drugs causing RPF:

  • Methyldopa
  • Methysergide
  • Amphetamines
  • Beta blockers
  • Cocaine
  • LSD

questions.text:
A 42 year old man presented with a 5 day history of bloody diarrhea. On examination, he was apyrexial, jaundiced and pale. There was no organomegaly but there was mild lower abdominal tenderness.Investigations reveal:
Hemoglobin 8.1 g/dL
White cell count 17500/μL
Platelets 70000/μL
urea 54 mg/dl
creatinine 2.0 mg/dl
aspartate aminotransferase 110 IU/L
Prothrombin time 12s (11.5-15.5)
Blood film shows fragmented red cells
What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The combination of haemolytic anaemia and thrombocytopenia in the setting of a normal coagulation profile is consistent with haemolytic uraemic syndrome HUS-TTPP). The fragmented cells are schistocytes, which are a consequence of small vessel thrombosis, which causes intravascular hemolysis.

The most likely cause of diarrhoea is E coli O157.

Hemolytic uremic syndrome (HUS) is characterised by the triad of microangiopathic hemolytic anaemia, thrombocytopenia, and acute renal failure. Diarrhoeaa and upper respiratory infection are the most common precipitating factors. Other bacterial agents include Shigella, Salmonella, Yersinia, and Campylobacter species.

questions.text: A 52-year-old man presents with lower back pain and lethargy. Investigations subsequently confirmed obstructive nephropathy and retroperitoneal fibrosis. His medication is reviewed during the ward round. Which medication is well known to cause retroperitoneal fibrosis?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Retroperitoneal fibrosis is a disease featuring the proliferation of fibrous tissue in the retroperitoneum, the compartment of the body containing the kidneys, aorta, renal tract and various other structures. It may present with lower back pain, renal failure, hypertension, deep vein thrombosis and other obstructive symptoms.

It may have an autoimmune aetiology. 1/3rd cases are secondary to malignancy, medications, aortic aneurysm or certain infections.

Methyldopa, methysergide, amphetamines, beta blockers, cocaine and LSD are drugs that cause retroperitoneal fibrosis.

Azathioprine is used to treat the condition.

questions.text: A 45-year-old male presents with weight loss and watery diarrhoea for several weeks. Investigations reveal hypokalaemia. Which of the following would support a diagnosis of a VIPoma?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

VIPomas in adults are usually neuroendocrine islet cell tumours of the pancreas that produce high amounts of VIP. Other secreted hormones may include secreted gastrin and pancreatic polypeptide.

Achlorhydria (lack of acidity from the stomach) is classically associated with VIPoma. It can be diagnosed by measuring acid output from nasogastric contents (NG tube). Features of VIP syndrome include watery diarrhoea, hypochlorhydria, hyperglycemia, hypercalcemia and flushing.

Hypoglycemia is associated with insulinoma.

Pellagra, a condition caused by niacin deficiency, occurs in carcinoid syndrome.

Migratory erythema associated with glucagonoma.

choices.text: Aspirin use is a risk factor for gastric carcinoma
Early diagnosis of gastric carcinoma results in a five year survival rate of 20%
Endoscopic ultrasonography is superior to conventional CT scanning for local tumour staging
Helicobacter pylori infection is not associated with gastric carcinoma

questions.text: Concerning gastric carcinoma, which of the following statements is true?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Computed tomography (CT) with gastric dilatation is a useful complementary investigation in the staging of gastric carcinoma, but endoscopic ultrasonography is superior to conventional CT scanning as it can assess depth of infiltration and lymphatic dissemination of the tumour.
  • Incidence of distal stomach tumours is decreasing while the incidence of tumours in the proximal stomach is increasing.
  • Nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drug (NSAID) use is associated with decreased risk of certain gastric tumours. (Option A ruled out)
  • Pylori infection has been associated in several studies with an increased risk of gastric carcinoma.(Option D ruled out)
  • Screening for gastric carcinoma in Japan detects up to 40% of gastric carcinomas at an early stage, and in skilled hands, five-year survival can be upwards of 90%. (Option B ruled out)

choices.text: Increased concentrations of C peptide are a marker of increased colorectal cancer risk
Insulin treatment increases recurrence-free survival after treatment of colonic cancer
The increased risk of colorectal cancer in diabetes is related to BMI
The increased risk of colorectal cancer in diabetes is related to total cholesterol

questions.text: Which of the following statements is correct concerning the relationship between type 2 diabetes and colonic cancer?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Several studies have independently linked high circulating concentrations of C-peptide, as a marker of insulin production, with increased colorectal cancer risk.
  • The molecular basis has not been proven, but it may be reasonable to extrapolate that it is linked to the growth-stimulating effects of insulin.
  • No association has been found between colonic malignancy and type 1 diabetes, nor gestational diabetes.
  • Type 2 diabetes is associated with a 40-60% increase in the risk of cancer of the large bowel. This increase is linked to changes in HbA1c. (Option C and D ruled out)
  • Type 2 diabetes is associated with significantly higher rates of overall mortality and reduced disease-free and recurrence-free survival after chemotherapy/radiotherapy, and insulin has not been shown to have any effects on mortality. (Option B ruled out)

questions.text: A 24-year-old anorexic is admitted for parenteral nutrition and has a tunnelled line inserted. A few days after parenteral feeding has begun, you are asked to see her as she has begun complaining of diplopia, lethargy and muscle weakness. She also has paraesthesia affecting her hands and feet. Examination confirms global muscle weakness and peripheral sensory loss. Which of the following electrolyte abnormalities is the most likely to have occurred?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

This patient is suffering from refeeding syndrome, where patients complain of a range of symptoms, where the above symptoms are due to hypophosphatemia.

Refeeding syndrome:

  • Refeeding Syndrome is a potentially fatal metabolic disturbance that arises when nutrition (enteral or parenteral) is reintroduced too rapidly after a period of prolonged fasting or malnutrition.
  • Even a few days of inadequate intake (e.g., <5â€¯days) can set the stage when feeding commences again.
  • High-risk groups include patients with anorexia, chronic illnesses (e.g. cystic fibrosis), long-term fasting, or those on TPN after malnutrition.

Characterised by:

  • Muscle weakness
  • Peripheral neuropathy
  • Neurological impairment
  • Myocardial depression.

Electrolyte abnormalities:

  • It is characterised by afall in phosphate, magnesium, potassium and fluid accumulation, which in combination can lead to cardiac failure. (Other options ruled out)

Management:

  • Continue feeding at cautious rates, adjust electrolytes as per lab findings.
  • Replace severe hypophosphatemia intravenously: e.g. 18mmol over 12h if serum phosphate <0.3 mmol/L.
  • Correct hypomagnesemia and hypokalemia alongside phosphate-magnesium correction helps potassium levels.
  • Treat thiamine deficiency aggressively.
  • Fluid balance: Restrict sodium and fluid if retention or oedema develops; consider diuretics if cardiac issues arise.

questions.text:
A 28-year-old woman presents to the Emergency department very agitated, complaining of abdominal pain. This has been her third attendance over the past six months, and each time there have been no significant findings. Her only medication of note is the oral contraceptive pill.
On this occasion her BP is elevated 155/90 mmHg, her pulse is 92, and her temperature is 37.8°C. Her abdomen is generally tender but soft, and she has active bowel sounds. She complains of lower limb weakness, and she appears to have 4/5 power weakness below the knee.Investigations show:
Hb 13.4 g/dl(13.5-18)
WCC 10.2 x 10^9/L (4-10)
PLT 194 x 10^9/L (150-400)
Na 132 mmol/l (134-143)
K 4.4 mmol/l (3.5-5)
Creatinine 1.1 mg/dl
Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

In the above given clinical case with hypertension, a mild increase in temperature and abdominal pain that is triggered by oestrogen intake points towards that of the Acute Intermittent Porphyria, which is an AD disorder.

Acute intermittent porphyria (AIP) is associated with:

  • Hypertension
  • A mild increase in temperature
  • Non-specific abdominal pain

Patients feel normal between attacks, and the disease itself is due to the accumulation of both porphobilinogen and amino-levulinic acid.

Drugs leading to Acute porphyria attacks:

  • In general, drugs that lead to increased activity of the hepatic P450 system, such as phenobarbital, sulfonamides, oestrogens, and alcohol, are associated with increased risk of acute attacks.

Explanation of other options:

Mesenteric adenitis(Option B): Usually seen in children or young adults with localised RLQ pain, mild systemic signs, and often following viral illnesses, not matching this pattern.

Munchausen's disease (factitious disorder)(Option C): Although multiple attendances with vague abdominal pain may suggest factitious behaviour, the presence of objective neurologic deficits (weakness, sensory loss), hypertension, agitation, and typical triggers makes an organic aetiology such as porphyria more probable.

Somatisation disorder(Option D): Similarly involves persistent physical complaints without pathology, but unlike functional disorders, this patient shows discrete neurological signs and systemic dysregulation consistent with a biochemical syndrome.

questions.text: A 44-year-old man presents with a six-month history of diarrhoea and abdominal cramps. On further questioning, it appears he has also noticed facial flushing. On examination, there is wheeze on auscultation of his chest, and abdominal examination reveals hepatomegaly. Which of the following investigations would confirm the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • This patient hascarcinoid syndrome.
  • The diagnosis is made by 24-hour urine collection for 5-hydroxyindoleacetic acid (5-HIAA) -excretion is greater than 0.3 mmol.

Carcinoid syndrome:

  • Carcinoid syndrome is a distinct constellation of symptoms caused by the release of biologically active substances, most notably serotonin, into the systemic circulation from neuroendocrine tumours (NETs).
  • Forty-five per cent of carcinoid tumours arise in the appendix, 30% arise in the small bowel and 20% in the rectum.
  • Most patients with carcinoid syndrome have liver metastases.
  • 5-HT, kinins, prostaglandins and other vasoactive substances are secreted.

Clinical features of carcinoid syndrome:

  • Diarrhoea and abdominal cramps in the majority of patients.
  • Flushing, which is often provoked by alcohol, bronchoconstriction and cardiac involvement with tricuspid or pulmonary incompetence are also features.

Diagnosis:

Chest x-ray, abdominal ultrasound scan, small bowel radiology and echocardiography to establish the extent of the disease.

Treatment:

Surgical resection of the primary tumour is possible in some cases; octreotide is the treatment of choice.

Explanation of other options:

24-hour urinary copper(Option B): In the majority of cases of Wilson's disease, 24-hour urinary copper is greater than 3 micromol.

24-hour urinary free cortisol(Option C): In Cushing's syndrome, 24-hour urinary free cortisol is elevated.

24-hour urinary protein(Option D): Nephrotic syndrome is defined as proteinuria greater than 3.5 g/1.75 m2 of body surface per 24 hours, hypoalbuminemia and oedema.

Screening for pheochromocytoma can be performed by 24-hour urine collection for 4-OH-3-methoxymandelate (HMMA, VMA).

questions.text: Which of the following demonstrates autosomal dominant inheritance?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Cystic fibrosis is an autosomal recessive disease, where mutations in the gene for the CFTR (cystic fibrosis transmembrane conductance regulator) result in the production of dry protein-rich secretions leading to pulmonary and gastrointestinal complications.

Dubin-Johnson syndrome is a rare autosomal recessive disorder where there is conjugated hyperbilirubinemia and impaired bilirubin excretion, resulting in mild jaundice but normal liver function.

Haemochromatosis demonstrates autosomal recessive inheritance, where iron overload can lead to cirrhosis.

Other systems are also affected, and patients may suffer from

  • Cardiomyopathy
  • Diabetes mellitus
  • Hypogonadism
  • Skin pigmentation ('bronze diabetes') and

Acute Intermittent Porphyria is a disorder inherited as an AD.

questions.text: Which of the following is a cause of macroglossia?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Macroglossia, Raccoon eyes, hepatomegaly, and anaemia are features of amyloidosis.

Crohn's disease can affect any part of the gastrointestinal tract from the mouth to the anus. Aphthous ulceration is common in active disease. Aphthous ulcers and glossitis are both features of celiac disease.

Patients with Peutz-Jeghers syndrome have characteristic mucocutaneous pigmentation that leads to perioral freckling.

choices.text: Endomysial antibody serology to investigate for coeliac disease should always be requested in addition to duodenal biopsies
Low serum iron with a low total iron-binding capacity confirms iron deficiency
Microcytosis may be absent where there is combined iron and folate deficiency
The presence of Howell-Jolly bodies on blood film would go against coeliac disease

questions.text: A 38-year-old woman is referred to the gastroenterology clinic. The patient has persistent lethargy, and blood results have demonstrated iron deficiency anaemia. Which of the following statements regarding iron deficiency anaemia is correct?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • In cases where both iron deficiency and folate (or B12) deficiency coexist, the typical microcytosis of iron deficiency may be offset by macrocytosis from folate deficiency, resulting in a normocytic or mixed red cell population and a normal mean corpuscular volume (MCV) despite anaemia.
  • The peripheral smear often shows dimorphic red cells and elevated RDW.
  • Distal duodenal (D2) biopsies should be taken in any patient with iron deficiency anaemia undergoing a gastroscopy, as 2-3% of patients will have celiac disease.
  • Endomysial antibody serology can be useful to confirm that subtotal villous atrophy found at histology is not due to another cause.
  • Antibody titres help to determine whether or not the patient is adhering to a gluten-free diet and are not always necessary with the biopsy. (Option A ruled out)
  • In the investigation of iron deficiency anaemia, a serology for coeliac disease would be performed before an OGD.
  • Low serum iron (< 10 pmol/L) with a high total iron-binding capacity (> 70 pmol/L) confirms iron deficiency.(Option B ruled out)
  • Howell-Jolly bodies on blood film indicate hyposplenism and are consistent with a diagnosis of coeliac disease. (Option D ruled out)
  • Thrombocytosis may occur in acute haemorrhage but is also found in several other situations, such as inflammatory conditions.

questions.text: A 23-year-old woman was referred for investigation of iron deficiency anaemia. Her mother died aged 28 years from colonic carcinoma complicating Peutz-Jegher syndrome. Which is the most likely mode of inheritance of Peutz-Jegher syndrome?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Peutz-Jegher syndrome is a condition characterised by perioral pigmentation and numerous hamartomas of the bowel. Originally, it was assumed that these did not predispose to malignancy, but studies now suggest the contrary. The condition is autosomal dominant.

questions.text: A 27-year-old woman was referred with tiredness and intermittent bloody diarrhoea, and a history of cerebral venous thrombosis. On examination, the sclera of the right eye was inflamed, and multiple mouth ulcers were noted. At the colonoscopy, which confirmed colitis, two large vulval ulcers were noted. Which is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • This is a classical description of the presentation of Behcet's, with oral and genital ulceration, colitis and scleritis.
  • Superficial or deep peripheral vein thrombosis is seen in 30% of patients. Arterial involvement occurs in <1-5% of patients and presents with aortitis or peripheral arterial aneurysm and arterial thrombosis.
  • Behçet's Disease (BD) is a chronic, relapsing, multisystem inflammatory vasculitis that can affect blood vessels of any size or type.
  • A genetic predisposition involving HLA-B51 is significant, though environmental triggers also contribute.

Explanation of other options:

Crohn's disease(Option B) can cause oral ulcers and colitis, but rarely causes genital ulcers, ocular inflammation, or cerebral venous thrombosis in combination.

HIV infection(Option C) can cause opportunistic oral ulcers and colitis, but would not produce such a constellation of recurrent genital aphthae, ocular inflammation, and occult thrombotic vascular events in this pattern

Ulcerative colitis(Option D) can be associated with CVT as a rare extraintestinal complication of active disease, but does not typically cause genital ulcers or ocular inflammation and rarely features the complex mucosal ulceration pattern of Behcet's.

questions.text:
A 44-year-old woman comes to the gastroenterology clinic for a review. She underwent extensive resection of her distal small bowel for Crohn's disease around three months earlier.She is still suffering from diarrhea and is worried that her Crohn's disease is still active. On examination her BP is 105/70 mmHg with a pulse of 80. Her abdomen is soft and nontender.
Investigations show
Hemoglobin 10.4 g/dl(13.5-8)
White cell count 4.5 x 10^9/L (4-10)
Platelets 195 x 10^9/L (150-400)
Sodium 138 mmol/l (134-143)
Potassium 3.4 mmol/l (3.5-5)
Creatinine 1.4 mg/dl
C reactive protein 9 mg/l (<10)
Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Bile acids are required for the absorption of fat. Cholic acid and Chenodeoxycholic acid are the primary bile acids that are conjugated by the liver with Taurine and Glycine, to maintain their levels in the small bowel, and facilitate the absorption of lipids.
  • Once the lipids are absorbed, the bile acids are reabsorbed by enterohepatic circulation from the terminal ileum.
  • So the disease processes that affect any of these steps will result in luminal deficiency of bile salt and malabsorption.

Bile acid and fatty acid Diarrhoea:

  • Of these, the diseases affecting the terminal ileum or if < 100cm of ileum is involved, cause spillage of the bile acids into the colon, causing diarrhoea.
  • This is Bile Acid Diarrhoea, and it will respond to bile acid binding resins. This will not be associated with steatorrhoea. (Option C ruled out)
  • If a large area of the ileum is affected,>100cm, there will be spillage of the bile acids into the colon, and also there will be malabsorption due to loss of large areas of the small bowel. This is called Fatty acid Diarrhoea.
  • This will not respond to Cholestyramine and will be associated with steatorrhoea.
  • We are told that this patient has undergone extensive distal small bowel resection, but she does not have an ileostomy.So she is likely suffering from Fatty acid diarrhoea.
  • Short bowel syndrome is usually associated with voluminous diarrhoea of up to 5 litres per day, normally through the ileostomy outlet.
  • There is no indication of active Crohn's disease, and bacterial overgrowth syndrome is usually associated with symptoms of abdominal bloating. (Option A and B ruled out)
  • Cholestyramine may be effective for the treatment of bile acid diarrhoea.
